thread.title: New Bern's annual Mumfest to headline a busy week
thread.title_full: New Bern's annual Mumfest to headline a busy week

author: Charlie Hall
title: New Bern's annual Mumfest to headline a busy week
text: New Bern's annual Mumfest to headline a busy week Week Ahead Best Bets: Top activities for the coming week. Posted Oct. 4, 2015 at 6:15 PM Updated at 6:20 PM Posted Oct. 4, 2015 at 6:15 PM Updated at 6:20 PM Week Ahead Best Bets: Top activities for the coming week. 1. Mumfest 2015 Mumfest, New Bern’s largest outdoor festival, will be Saturday and Sunday in downtown, and will include a Friday night kickoff concert at Tryon Palace. Attractions, including 300 vendors along with special events such as the expanded boat show, a new Art in the Park venture and many local nonprofits and special demonstrations, will begin at 9:30 a.m. Saturday and Sunday. Mumfest is a city-sponsored event produced by Swiss Bear Downtown Development Corp. On the web: mumfest.com Contact 635-1747. 2. Concert for upcoming Alzheimer’s Walk There will be a Saturday event in conjunction with the Oct. 24 New Bern Walk to End Alzheimer’s. Home Instead Senior Care will present the Tone Peddlers. There is a $5 per person cover at the door, and all money raised at the door will go to the 2015 New Bern Walk to End Alzheimer’s. The Tone Peddlers will perform after Mumfest in the Isaac Taylor Garden, 228 Craven St. The concert will begin at 6:30 p.m. The New Bern Walk to End Alzheimer’s on Oct. 24 will have 10 a.m. registration at the Galley Store and Marina on East Front Street. 3. RiverTowne Players children’s musical RiverTowne Players of New Bern will continue its children’s musical —“My Son Pinocchio JR.”— with 7:30 p.m. shows Friday and Saturday at the Masonic Theatre, along with a 3 p.m. Sunday matinee. The theater is at 514 Hancock St. Tickets are $10 in advance, $12 at the door. Buy tickets on the web: ShowTix4u.com Call 638-8024. 4. Greenwood grave markers ceremony The Greenwood Cemetery Project recently restored six wooden grave markers, and a “Blessing of the Greenwood Grave Markers” is set for Sunday in New Bern. The ceremony will be at 4 p.m. at First Missionary Baptist Church, 819 Cypress St. The project was developed by the Uptown Business and Professional Association. It came from research from that group’s “Trail of Flames” tour. The speakers and their topics will include: “History of Cedar Grove and Greenwood Connection,” by Alice Ruckart; “First Missionary Baptist History,” by Dorothy Bryan; “History of Greenwood Cemetery Records,” by Thurman Hardison; “These Six Markers and Who is Buried in Greenwood,” by Donna Rhein; and “Why Cemeteries Matter?” by Mary Peterkin. 5. Tryon Palace events Page 2 of 4 - Tryon Palace gardens will be open for free during Mumfest weekend, Friday through Sunday. Hundreds of mums and a variety of fall blooming plants will be on display throughout the 16 acres of gardens. The Fall Heritage Plant Sale will also be held Friday and Saturday on the Daves House Lawn. This annual plant sale offers a selection of plants grown locally and in the Palace’s nursery yard, as well as a wide variety of perennials, herbs, fall vegetables and more. Both the Tryon Palace Craft and Garden Shop and the Museum Store will be open Friday and Saturday with a storewide sale. The Tryon Palace Fife and Drum Corps will perform Saturday at 11 a.m. and 1 p.m. Gardens will be free and open to the public Friday from 9 a.m. to 4:30 p.m.; Saturday from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.; and Sunday from noon to 6 p.m. For complete Palace programing this week, visit tryonpalace.org on the web or call 639-3500. Here are some other events that should be on your radar: ■ The New Bern-Craven County Public Library has a number of events this week at 400 Johnson St. On Monday, there will be World of eBooks at 2:30 p.m., a chance to learn how to check out eBooks eAudiobooks from the library. Computer skills are not required. Also Monday, at 7:30 p.m., there will be a session of “Let’s Talk About It — Writers from N.C.’s Literary Hall of Fame.” The discussion is “The Winter People” by John Ehle. The talk will be led by Bill BiNome, from the UNC-Wilmington Auditorium. On Wednesday and again Oct. 14 and 21, there will be another session of “Lunch ‘n Learn: Eat Smart, Move More, Weigh Less.” Bring a lunch and learn about a healthy lifestyle. Also Wednesday, there will be a session on Android Tables at 2:30 p.m. A tablet is needed. On Thursday, the Senior Graphic Novel Club will meet at 6 p.m., for ages 17 to 21. They will discuss elements of the Eisner Award winning series “Saga” by Brian K. Vaughan and Fiona Staples. Saturday will have the Teen Library Council meeting at 10 a.m. They will plan to promote and help the library. ■ The monthly ArtWalk will begin at 5 p.m. Friday in downtown New Bern. It will include galleries, studios and participating and supporting shops, restaurants and businesses. It is sponsored by the Craven Arts Council & Gallery. On the web: cravenarts.org Call 638-2577. Page 3 of 4 - ■ A special “MUM ARTcrawl” is planned Friday by its organizers, Community Artist Will. It will begin at 5 p.m., with galleries, studios and shops participating, along with art and performance venues. For a map, stop by Community Artist Will, 228 Craven St., or visit communityartistwill.org on the web. Call Lisa Bisbee Lentz at 649-1712. ■ The New Bern Firemen’s Museum Fire House will have an open house Saturday and Sunday at the new location, 420 Broad St. It will be from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. each day. The public is invited to tour the 1928 Fire House Open House. Admission is free. On the web: newbernfiremuseum.com ■ Oriental’s History Museum invites the public to celebrate the town’s history at Jukebox Jam, the museum’s second annual street dance on Saturday from 4 to 7 p.m. It will feature the museum’s Wurlitzer jukebox from Red Lee’s Grill, along with Cheryl Thompson as the DJ. The Jukebox Jam afternoon of music and dancing is a fundraiser for Oriental’s History Museum, which is 10 years old. There will be hot dogs for sale. The Oriental History Museum is located at 802 Broad St. Email museum@dockline.net ■ The Pamlico Community College Foundation will host its fifth annual Rufus Brinson Dinner Dance on Saturday. The 5:30 p.m. event raises funds for the Rufus Brinson Fund, which provides scholarships and training for emergency services students. The program was headed by the late Brinson, who was also a longtime Reelsboro VFD chief and firefighter. Tickets for the dinner and dance are $25. Dance tickets only are $15. Call 249-1851, ext. 3010. ■ The Coastal Environmental Partnership sponsors its series of Household Hazardous Waste and Electronics Collection Days in Carteret, Craven and Pamlico counties. Area sites for Saturday will be the Pamlico County Courthouse in Bayboro from 9 a.m. to noon, and 8 a.m. to 1 p.m. at Craven Community College’s New Bern campus, 800 College Court. Accepted items include latex and oil paints; used motor oil; lawn and garden fertilizer and pesticides; gasoline; drain openers; paint thinners; cooking oil; anti-freeze and batteries. For information, call 636-6659 in Craven County or 745-4240 in Pamlico County. ■ Coastal Women’s Shelter and New Bern Parks and Recreation will host the inaugural 5K and 1-mile fundraiser run/walk on Sunday. Proceeds go toward domestic violence services in Craven, Pamlico and Jones counties. Races will begin and end at Union Point Park in New Bern, with routes through the historic downtown district. Page 4 of 4 - Registration and packet pick-up will begin at 6 a.m., with races beginning at 7:30 a.m. Awards will be given in the 5K. Call 638-4509 or 639-2907 and ask for Trevor Freitas. On the web: coastalwomensshelter.org Online registration: active.com ■ The Handbell Musicians Concert will be Sunday at 4 p.m. in the New Bern Riverfront Convention Center. The event will have advanced English handbell musicians from around the country, under the direction of Beth Watson. The event is “Distinctly Bronze East,” the Handbell Musicians of America’s premier performance event for advanced handbell musicians. Ringers will rehearse at the convention center beginning Thursday. Call 937-438-0085.
